documents.title: Cystic Fibrosis
documents.content:
Disease: Cystic Fibrosis
Also known as: CF, Mucoviscidosis

Genes: CFTR
Inheritance: Autosomal recessive
Prevalence: 1 in 2,500-3,500 Caucasians
Age of Onset: Neonatal/Infancy

Description:
Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the CFTR gene, which encodes a chloride channel. The disease primarily affects the lungs, pancreas, liver, intestines, and reproductive system. Defective chloride transport leads to thick, viscous secretions that obstruct airways and ducts. Progressive lung disease is the primary cause of morbidity and mortality.

Clinical Features:
• Chronic pulmonary infections
• Pancreatic insufficiency
• Elevated sweat chloride
• Male infertility (absent vas deferens)
• Meconium ileus in newborns
• Bronchiectasis
• Nasal polyps
• Hepatobiliary disease

OMIM ID: 219700

documents.title: Huntington's Disease
documents.content:
Disease: Huntington's Disease
Also known as: HD, Huntington's Chorea

Genes: HTT
Inheritance: Autosomal dominant
Prevalence: 3-7 per 100,000 in Western populations
Age of Onset: Adult onset (30-50 years typically)

Description:
Huntington's disease is an autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disorder caused by CAG trinucleotide repeat expansion in the HTT gene. The mutation results in an abnormally long polyglutamine tract in the huntingtin protein, leading to neuronal dysfunction and death, particularly in the striatum and cortex. The disease is characterized by a triad of motor, cognitive, and psychiatric symptoms.

Clinical Features:
• Chorea (involuntary movements)
• Progressive dementia
• Psychiatric disturbances
• Depression
• Personality changes
• Impaired judgment
• Dysarthria
• Dysphagia
• Gait abnormalities

OMIM ID: 143100

documents.title: Sickle Cell Disease
documents.content:
Disease: Sickle Cell Disease
Also known as: SCD, Sickle Cell Anemia, HbSS Disease

Genes: HBB
Inheritance: Autosomal recessive
Prevalence: 1 in 365 African Americans
Age of Onset: Infancy (after fetal hemoglobin decline)

Description:
Sickle cell disease is an autosomal recessive hemoglobinopathy caused by a point mutation in the HBB gene, resulting in production of abnormal hemoglobin S (HbS). Under low oxygen conditions, HbS polymerizes causing red blood cells to assume a rigid sickle shape. These deformed cells cause vaso-occlusion, hemolysis, and progressive organ damage.

Clinical Features:
• Vaso-occlusive pain crises
• Chronic hemolytic anemia
• Splenic sequestration
• Acute chest syndrome
• Stroke
• Avascular necrosis
• Leg ulcers
• Priapism
• Increased infection susceptibility

OMIM ID: 603903

documents.title: Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy
documents.content:
Disease: Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy
Also known as: DMD, Pseudohypertrophic Muscular Dystrophy

Genes: DMD
Inheritance: X-linked recessive
Prevalence: 1 in 3,500-5,000 male births
Age of Onset: Early childhood (2-5 years)

Description:
Duchenne muscular dystrophy is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by mutations in the DMD gene encoding dystrophin. Absence of functional dystrophin leads to progressive muscle fiber degeneration and replacement by fibrotic and adipose tissue. It is the most common and severe form of muscular dystrophy.

Clinical Features:
• Progressive proximal muscle weakness
• Pseudohypertrophy of calves
• Gowers sign
• Cardiomyopathy
• Respiratory insufficiency
• Elevated creatine kinase
• Loss of ambulation (by age 12)
• Scoliosis
• Cognitive impairment

OMIM ID: 310200

documents.title: Phenylketonuria
documents.content:
Disease: Phenylketonuria
Also known as: PKU, Phenylalanine Hydroxylase Deficiency

Genes: PAH
Inheritance: Autosomal recessive
Prevalence: 1 in 10,000-15,000 births
Age of Onset: Neonatal (detectable at birth)

Description:
Phenylketonuria is an autosomal recessive inborn error of metabolism caused by deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH), the enzyme that converts phenylalanine to tyrosine. Accumulation of phenylalanine and its metabolites causes irreversible intellectual disability if untreated. Newborn screening and dietary restriction of phenylalanine can prevent neurological damage.

Clinical Features:
• Intellectual disability (if untreated)
• Seizures
• Musty body odor
• Fair skin and hair (hypopigmentation)
• Eczema
• Behavioral problems
• Microcephaly
• Hyperactivity

OMIM ID: 261600

documents.title: Marfan Syndrome
documents.content:
Disease: Marfan Syndrome
Also known as: MFS

Genes: FBN1
Inheritance: Autosomal dominant
Prevalence: 1 in 5,000-10,000
Age of Onset: Variable (childhood to adult)

Description:
Marfan syndrome is an autosomal dominant connective tissue disorder caused by mutations in the FBN1 gene encoding fibrillin-1. The condition affects multiple organ systems including the cardiovascular, skeletal, and ocular systems. Aortic root dilation and dissection are the primary causes of morbidity and mortality.

Clinical Features:
• Aortic root dilation
• Mitral valve prolapse
• Ectopia lentis (lens dislocation)
• Tall stature with long limbs
• Arachnodactyly
• Pectus excavatum/carinatum
• Scoliosis
• Joint hypermobility
• Dural ectasia
• Spontaneous pneumothorax

OMIM ID: 154700

documents.title: Hereditary Breast and Ovarian Cancer Syndrome
documents.content:
Disease: Hereditary Breast and Ovarian Cancer Syndrome
Also known as: HBOC, BRCA-related Cancer

Genes: BRCA1, BRCA2
Inheritance: Autosomal dominant
Prevalence: 1 in 300-500 (general); 1 in 40 (Ashkenazi Jewish)
Age of Onset: Adult (cancer risk increases with age)

Description:
Hereditary breast and ovarian cancer syndrome is caused by germline mutations in BRCA1 or BRCA2 genes, which encode proteins involved in DNA repair. Mutations significantly increase lifetime risk of breast cancer (50-85%) and ovarian cancer (15-45%). The condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern with incomplete penetrance.

Clinical Features:
• Early-onset breast cancer
• Bilateral breast cancer
• Ovarian cancer
• Male breast cancer
• Pancreatic cancer
• Prostate cancer (BRCA2)
• Triple-negative breast cancer (BRCA1)

OMIM ID: 604370

documents.title: Hemophilia A
documents.content:
Disease: Hemophilia A
Also known as: Classic Hemophilia, Factor VIII Deficiency

Genes: F8
Inheritance: X-linked recessive
Prevalence: 1 in 5,000 male births
Age of Onset: Infancy/early childhood

Description:
Hemophilia A is an X-linked recessive bleeding disorder caused by deficiency of coagulation factor VIII. The severity of bleeding correlates with factor VIII activity levels. Patients experience spontaneous and trauma-induced bleeding, particularly into joints and muscles, leading to chronic arthropathy without proper treatment.

Clinical Features:
• Hemarthrosis (joint bleeding)
• Muscle hematomas
• Prolonged bleeding after injury
• Easy bruising
• Intracranial hemorrhage
• Chronic arthropathy
• Excessive post-surgical bleeding

OMIM ID: 306700

documents.title: Down Syndrome
documents.content:
Disease: Down Syndrome
Also known as: Trisomy 21, DS

Genes: Chromosome 21 trisomy
Inheritance: Chromosomal (usually de novo)
Prevalence: 1 in 700-800 live births
Age of Onset: Congenital

Description:
Down syndrome is the most common chromosomal abnormality, caused by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 21 (trisomy 21). The condition results from nondisjunction during meiosis. It is characterized by intellectual disability, distinctive facial features, and an increased risk of various medical conditions including congenital heart defects.

Clinical Features:
• Intellectual disability
• Characteristic facial features
• Congenital heart defects (40-50%)
• Hypotonia
• Short stature
• Atlantoaxial instability
• Hypothyroidism
• Increased leukemia risk
• Early-onset Alzheimer disease
• Hearing loss

OMIM ID: 190685

documents.title: Fragile X Syndrome
documents.content:
Disease: Fragile X Syndrome
Also known as: FXS, Martin-Bell Syndrome

Genes: FMR1
Inheritance: X-linked dominant
Prevalence: 1 in 4,000 males; 1 in 8,000 females
Age of Onset: Early childhood

Description:
Fragile X syndrome is the most common inherited cause of intellectual disability and the most common single-gene cause of autism spectrum disorder. It is caused by CGG repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene, leading to gene silencing and loss of FMRP protein. The condition shows X-linked dominant inheritance with reduced penetrance in females.

Clinical Features:
• Intellectual disability
• Autism spectrum features
• Attention deficit
• Anxiety
• Long face
• Large ears
• Macroorchidism (post-pubertal)
• Joint hypermobility
• Mitral valve prolapse
• Seizures

OMIM ID: 300624

documents.title: Neurofibromatosis Type 1
documents.content:
Disease: Neurofibromatosis Type 1
Also known as: NF1, Von Recklinghausen Disease

Genes: NF1
Inheritance: Autosomal dominant
Prevalence: 1 in 3,000
Age of Onset: Early childhood (progressive)

Description:
Neurofibromatosis type 1 is an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous disorder caused by mutations in the NF1 gene encoding neurofibromin, a tumor suppressor. The condition is characterized by café-au-lait spots, neurofibromas, and increased risk of various tumors. It is one of the most common single-gene disorders.

Clinical Features:
• Café-au-lait macules
• Neurofibromas
• Axillary/inguinal freckling
• Lisch nodules (iris hamartomas)
• Optic glioma
• Skeletal abnormalities
• Learning disabilities
• Increased malignancy risk
• Hypertension

OMIM ID: 162200

documents.title: Tay-Sachs Disease
documents.content:
Disease: Tay-Sachs Disease
Also known as: GM2 Gangliosidosis Type 1, Hexosaminidase A Deficiency

Genes: HEXA
Inheritance: Autosomal recessive
Prevalence: 1 in 320,000 (general); 1 in 3,600 (Ashkenazi Jewish)
Age of Onset: Infantile (3-6 months)

Description:
Tay-Sachs disease is an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder caused by deficiency of hexosaminidase A, leading to accumulation of GM2 ganglioside in neurons. The infantile form is characterized by progressive neurodegeneration and death in early childhood. Later-onset forms exist with variable severity.

Clinical Features:
• Developmental regression
• Cherry-red spot (macula)
• Hypotonia progressing to spasticity
• Seizures
• Blindness
• Deafness
• Exaggerated startle response
• Macrocephaly
• Dementia

OMIM ID: 272800

documents.title: Alpha-1 Antitrypsin Deficiency
documents.content:
Disease: Alpha-1 Antitrypsin Deficiency
Also known as: A1AD, AAT Deficiency, SERPINA1 Deficiency

Genes: SERPINA1
Inheritance: Autosomal codominant
Prevalence: 1 in 2,000-5,000 (European descent)
Age of Onset: Adult (lung disease); Variable (liver disease)

Description:
Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency is an autosomal codominant disorder caused by mutations in SERPINA1, encoding the protease inhibitor alpha-1 antitrypsin. Deficiency leads to unopposed neutrophil elastase activity in the lungs (causing emphysema) and accumulation of misfolded protein in the liver (causing cirrhosis).

Clinical Features:
• Early-onset emphysema
• COPD
• Liver cirrhosis
• Hepatocellular carcinoma
• Panniculitis
• Bronchiectasis
• Neonatal jaundice

OMIM ID: 613490

documents.title: Wilson's Disease
documents.content:
Disease: Wilson's Disease
Also known as: Hepatolenticular Degeneration, WD

Genes: ATP7B
Inheritance: Autosomal recessive
Prevalence: 1 in 30,000
Age of Onset: Childhood to young adult

Description:
Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder of copper metabolism caused by mutations in ATP7B, encoding a copper-transporting ATPase. Impaired copper excretion leads to accumulation in the liver, brain, and other tissues. Early treatment with copper chelation or zinc can prevent irreversible damage.

Clinical Features:
• Hepatic disease (hepatitis, cirrhosis)
• Kayser-Fleischer rings
• Neuropsychiatric symptoms
• Tremor
• Dysarthria
• Dystonia
• Depression
• Hemolytic anemia
• Renal tubular dysfunction

OMIM ID: 277900

documents.title: Lynch Syndrome
documents.content:
Disease: Lynch Syndrome
Also known as: HNPCC, Hereditary Non-Polyposis Colorectal Cancer

Genes: MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, PMS2, EPCAM
Inheritance: Autosomal dominant
Prevalence: 1 in 300-500
Age of Onset: Adult (cancer risk increases with age)

Description:
Lynch syndrome is an autosomal dominant cancer predisposition syndrome caused by germline mutations in DNA mismatch repair genes (MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, PMS2) or EPCAM deletions. It significantly increases risk of colorectal, endometrial, and other cancers. Tumors characteristically show microsatellite instability.

Clinical Features:
• Colorectal cancer (high risk)
• Endometrial cancer
• Ovarian cancer
• Gastric cancer
• Urinary tract cancer
• Sebaceous neoplasms
• Brain tumors (Turcot syndrome)
• Early age of cancer onset

OMIM ID: 120435
